02319 1;
02320 
02321 __END__
02322 
02323 =head1 NAME
02324 
02325 MatrixReal1 - Matrix of Reals
02326 
02327 Implements the data type "matrix of reals" (and consequently also
02328 "vector of reals")
02329 
02330 =head1 DESCRIPTION
02331 
02332 Implements the data type "matrix of reals", which can be used almost
02333 like any other basic Perl type thanks to B<OPERATOR OVERLOADING>, i.e.,
02334 
02335   $product = $matrix1 * $matrix2;
02336 
02337 does what you would like it to do (a matrix multiplication).
02338 
02339 Also features many important operations and methods: matrix norm,
02340 matrix transposition, matrix inverse, determinant of a matrix, order
02341 and numerical condition of a matrix, scalar product of vectors, vector
02342 product of vectors, vector length, projection of row and column vectors,
02343 a comfortable way for reading in a matrix from a file, the keyboard or
02344 your code, and many more.
02345 
02346 Allows to solve linear equation systems using an efficient algorithm
02347 known as "L-R-decomposition" and several approximative (iterative) methods.
02348 
02349 Features an implementation of Kleene's algorithm to compute the minimal
02350 costs for all paths in a graph with weighted edges (the "weights" being
02351 the costs associated with each edge).
02352 
02353 =head1 SYNOPSIS
02354 
02355 =over 2
02356 
02357 =item *
02358 
02359 C<use MatrixReal1;>
02360 
02361 Makes the methods and overloaded operators of this module available
02362 to your program.
02363 
02364 =item *
02365 
02366 C<use MatrixReal1 qw(min max);>
02367 
02368 =item *
02369 
02370 C<use MatrixReal1 qw(:all);>
02371 
02372 Use one of these two variants to import (all) the functions which the module
02373 offers for export; currently these are "min()" and "max()".
02374 
02375 =item *
02376 
02377 C<$new_matrix = new MatrixReal1($rows,$columns);>
02378 
02379 The matrix object constructor method.
02380 
02381 Note that this method is implicitly called by many of the other methods
02382 in this module!
02383 
02384 =item *
02385 
02386 C<$new_matrix = MatrixReal1-E<gt>>C<new($rows,$columns);>
02387 
02388 An alternate way of calling the matrix object constructor method.
02389 
02390 =item *
02391 
02392 C<$new_matrix = $some_matrix-E<gt>>C<new($rows,$columns);>
02393 
02394 Still another way of calling the matrix object constructor method.
02395 
02396 Matrix "C<$some_matrix>" is not changed by this in any way.
02397 
02398 =item *
02399 
02400 C<$new_matrix = MatrixReal1-E<gt>>C<new_from_string($string);>
02401 
02402 This method allows you to read in a matrix from a string (for
02403 instance, from the keyboard, from a file or from your code).
02404 
02405 The syntax is simple: each row must start with "C<[ >" and end with
02406 "C< ]\n>" ("C<\n>" being the newline character and "C< >" a space or
02407 tab) and contain one or more numbers, all separated from each other
02408 by spaces or tabs.
02409 
02410 Additional spaces or tabs can be added at will, but no comments.
02411 
02412 Examples:
02413 
02414   $string = "[ 1 2 3 ]\n[ 2 2 -1 ]\n[ 1 1 1 ]\n";
02415   $matrix = MatrixReal1->new_from_string($string);
02416   print "$matrix";
02417 
02418 By the way, this prints
02419 
02420   [  1.000000000000E+00  2.000000000000E+00  3.000000000000E+00 ]
02421   [  2.000000000000E+00  2.000000000000E+00 -1.000000000000E+00 ]
02422   [  1.000000000000E+00  1.000000000000E+00  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02423 
02424 But you can also do this in a much more comfortable way using the
02425 shell-like "here-document" syntax:
02426 
02427   $matrix = MatrixReal1->new_from_string(<<'MATRIX');
02428   [  1  0  0  0  0  0  1  ]
02429   [  0  1  0  0  0  0  0  ]
02430   [  0  0  1  0  0  0  0  ]
02431   [  0  0  0  1  0  0  0  ]
02432   [  0  0  0  0  1  0  0  ]
02433   [  0  0  0  0  0  1  0  ]
02434   [  1  0  0  0  0  0 -1  ]
02435   MATRIX
02436 
02437 You can even use variables in the matrix:
02438 
02439   $c1 =   2  /  3;
02440   $c2 =  -2  /  5;
02441   $c3 =  26  /  9;
02442 
02443   $matrix = MatrixReal1->new_from_string(<<"MATRIX");
02444 
02445       [   3    2    0   ]
02446       [   0    3    2   ]
02447       [  $c1  $c2  $c3  ]
02448 
02449   MATRIX
02450 
02451 (Remember that you may use spaces and tabs to format the matrix to
02452 your taste)
02453 
02454 Note that this method uses exactly the same representation for a
02455 matrix as the "stringify" operator "": this means that you can convert
02456 any matrix into a string with C<$string = "$matrix";> and read it back
02457 in later (for instance from a file!).
02458 
02459 Note however that you may suffer a precision loss in this process
02460 because only 13 digits are supported in the mantissa when printed!!
02461 
02462 If the string you supply (or someone else supplies) does not obey
02463 the syntax mentioned above, an exception is raised, which can be
02464 caught by "eval" as follows:
02465 
02466   print "Please enter your matrix (in one line): ";
02467   $string = <STDIN>;
02468   $string =~ s/\\n/\n/g;
02469   eval { $matrix = MatrixReal1->new_from_string($string); };
02470   if ($@)
02471   {
02472       print "$@";
02473       # ...
02474       # (error handling)
02475   }
02476   else
02477   {
02478       # continue...
02479   }
02480 
02481 or as follows:
02482 
02483   eval { $matrix = MatrixReal1->new_from_string(<<"MATRIX"); };
02484   [   3    2    0   ]
02485   [   0    3    2   ]
02486   [  $c1  $c2  $c3  ]
02487   MATRIX
02488   if ($@)
02489   # ...
02490 
02491 Actually, the method shown above for reading a matrix from the keyboard
02492 is a little awkward, since you have to enter a lot of "\n"'s for the
02493 newlines.
02494 
02495 A better way is shown in this piece of code:
02496 
02497   while (1)
02498   {
02499       print "\nPlease enter your matrix ";
02500       print "(multiple lines, <ctrl-D> = done):\n";
02501       eval { $new_matrix =
02502           MatrixReal1->new_from_string(join('',<STDIN>)); };
02503       if ($@)
02504       {
02505           $@ =~ s/\s+at\b.*?$//;
02506           print "${@}Please try again.\n";
02507       }
02508       else { last; }
02509   }
02510 
02511 Possible error messages of the "new_from_string()" method are:
02512 
02513   MatrixReal1::new_from_string(): syntax error in input string
02514   MatrixReal1::new_from_string(): empty input string
02515 
02516 If the input string has rows with varying numbers of columns,
02517 the following warning will be printed to STDERR:
02518 
02519   MatrixReal1::new_from_string(): missing elements will be set to zero!
02520 
02521 If everything is okay, the method returns an object reference to the
02522 (newly allocated) matrix containing the elements you specified.
02523 
02524 =item *
02525 
02526 C<$new_matrix = $some_matrix-E<gt>shadow();>
02527 
02528 Returns an object reference to a B<NEW> but B<EMPTY> matrix
02529 (filled with zero's) of the B<SAME SIZE> as matrix "C<$some_matrix>".
02530 
02531 Matrix "C<$some_matrix>" is not changed by this in any way.
02532 
02533 =item *
02534 
02535 C<$matrix1-E<gt>copy($matrix2);>
02536 
02537 Copies the contents of matrix "C<$matrix2>" to an B<ALREADY EXISTING>
02538 matrix "C<$matrix1>" (which must have the same size as matrix "C<$matrix2>"!).
02539 
02540 Matrix "C<$matrix2>" is not changed by this in any way.
02541 
02542 =item *
02543 
02544 C<$twin_matrix = $some_matrix-E<gt>clone();>
02545 
02546 Returns an object reference to a B<NEW> matrix of the B<SAME SIZE> as
02547 matrix "C<$some_matrix>". The contents of matrix "C<$some_matrix>" have
02548 B<ALREADY BEEN COPIED> to the new matrix "C<$twin_matrix>".
02549 
02550 Matrix "C<$some_matrix>" is not changed by this in any way.
02551 
02552 =item *
02553 
02554 C<$row_vector = $matrix-E<gt>row($row);>
02555 
02556 This is a projection method which returns an object reference to
02557 a B<NEW> matrix (which in fact is a (row) vector since it has only
02558 one row) to which row number "C<$row>" of matrix "C<$matrix>" has
02559 already been copied.
02560 
02561 Matrix "C<$matrix>" is not changed by this in any way.
02562 
02563 =item *
02564 
02565 C<$column_vector = $matrix-E<gt>column($column);>
02566 
02567 This is a projection method which returns an object reference to
02568 a B<NEW> matrix (which in fact is a (column) vector since it has
02569 only one column) to which column number "C<$column>" of matrix
02570 "C<$matrix>" has already been copied.
02571 
02572 Matrix "C<$matrix>" is not changed by this in any way.
02573 
02574 =item *
02575 
02576 C<$matrix-E<gt>zero();>
02577 
02578 Assigns a zero to every element of the matrix "C<$matrix>", i.e.,
02579 erases all values previously stored there, thereby effectively
02580 transforming the matrix into a "zero"-matrix or "null"-matrix,
02581 the neutral element of the addition operation in a Ring.
02582 
02583 (For instance the (quadratic) matrices with "n" rows and columns
02584 and matrix addition and multiplication form a Ring. Most prominent
02585 characteristic of a Ring is that multiplication is not commutative,
02586 i.e., in general, "C<matrix1 * matrix2>" is not the same as
02587 "C<matrix2 * matrix1>"!)
02588 
02589 =item *
02590 
02591 C<$matrix-E<gt>one();>
02592 
02593 Assigns one's to the elements on the main diagonal (elements (1,1),
02594 (2,2), (3,3) and so on) of matrix "C<$matrix>" and zero's to all others,
02595 thereby erasing all values previously stored there and transforming the
02596 matrix into a "one"-matrix, the neutral element of the multiplication
02597 operation in a Ring.
02598 
02599 (If the matrix is quadratic (which this method doesn't require, though),
02600 then multiplying this matrix with itself yields this same matrix again,
02601 and multiplying it with some other matrix leaves that other matrix
02602 unchanged!)
02603 
02604 =item *
02605 
02606 C<$matrix-E<gt>assign($row,$column,$value);>
02607 
02608 Explicitly assigns a value "C<$value>" to a single element of the
02609 matrix "C<$matrix>", located in row "C<$row>" and column "C<$column>",
02610 thereby replacing the value previously stored there.
02611 
02612 =item *
02613 
02614 C<$value = $matrix-E<gt>>C<element($row,$column);>
02615 
02616 Returns the value of a specific element of the matrix "C<$matrix>",
02617 located in row "C<$row>" and column "C<$column>".
02618 
02619 =item *
02620 
02621 C<($rows,$columns) = $matrix-E<gt>dim();>
02622 
02623 Returns a list of two items, representing the number of rows
02624 and columns the given matrix "C<$matrix>" contains.
02625 
02626 =item *
02627 
02628 C<$norm_one = $matrix-E<gt>norm_one();>
02629 
02630 Returns the "one"-norm of the given matrix "C<$matrix>".
02631 
02632 The "one"-norm is defined as follows:
02633 
02634 For each column, the sum of the absolute values of the elements in the
02635 different rows of that column is calculated. Finally, the maximum
02636 of these sums is returned.
02637 
02638 Note that the "one"-norm and the "maximum"-norm are mathematically
02639 equivalent, although for the same matrix they usually yield a different
02640 value.
02641 
02642 Therefore, you should only compare values that have been calculated
02643 using the same norm!
02644 
02645 Throughout this package, the "one"-norm is (arbitrarily) used
02646 for all comparisons, for the sake of uniformity and comparability,
02647 except for the iterative methods "solve_GSM()", "solve_SSM()" and
02648 "solve_RM()" which use either norm depending on the matrix itself.
02649 
02650 =item *
02651 
02652 C<$norm_max = $matrix-E<gt>norm_max();>
02653 
02654 Returns the "maximum"-norm of the given matrix "C<$matrix>".
02655 
02656 The "maximum"-norm is defined as follows:
02657 
02658 For each row, the sum of the absolute values of the elements in the
02659 different columns of that row is calculated. Finally, the maximum
02660 of these sums is returned.
02661 
02662 Note that the "maximum"-norm and the "one"-norm are mathematically
02663 equivalent, although for the same matrix they usually yield a different
02664 value.
02665 
02666 Therefore, you should only compare values that have been calculated
02667 using the same norm!
02668 
02669 Throughout this package, the "one"-norm is (arbitrarily) used
02670 for all comparisons, for the sake of uniformity and comparability,
02671 except for the iterative methods "solve_GSM()", "solve_SSM()" and
02672 "solve_RM()" which use either norm depending on the matrix itself.
02673 
02674 =item *
02675 
02676 C<$matrix1-E<gt>negate($matrix2);>
02677 
02678 Calculates the negative of matrix "C<$matrix2>" (i.e., multiplies
02679 all elements with "-1") and stores the result in matrix "C<$matrix1>"
02680 (which must already exist and have the same size as matrix "C<$matrix2>"!).
02681 
02682 This operation can also be carried out "in-place", i.e., input and
02683 output matrix may be identical.
02684 
02685 =item *
02686 
02687 C<$matrix1-E<gt>transpose($matrix2);>
02688 
02689 Calculates the transposed matrix of matrix "C<$matrix2>" and stores
02690 the result in matrix "C<$matrix1>" (which must already exist and have
02691 the same size as matrix "C<$matrix2>"!).
02692 
02693 This operation can also be carried out "in-place", i.e., input and
02694 output matrix may be identical.
02695 
02696 Transposition is a symmetry operation: imagine you rotate the matrix
02697 along the axis of its main diagonal (going through elements (1,1),
02698 (2,2), (3,3) and so on) by 180 degrees.
02699 
02700 Another way of looking at it is to say that rows and columns are
02701 swapped. In fact the contents of element C<(i,j)> are swapped
02702 with those of element C<(j,i)>.
02703 
02704 Note that (especially for vectors) it makes a big difference if you
02705 have a row vector, like this:
02706 
02707   [ -1 0 1 ]
02708 
02709 or a column vector, like this:
02710 
02711   [ -1 ]
02712   [  0 ]
02713   [  1 ]
02714 
02715 the one vector being the transposed of the other!
02716 
02717 This is especially true for the matrix product of two vectors:
02718 
02719                [ -1 ]
02720   [ -1 0 1 ] * [  0 ]  =  [ 2 ] ,  whereas
02721                [  1 ]
02722 
02723                              *     [ -1  0  1 ]
02724   [ -1 ]                                            [  1  0 -1 ]
02725   [  0 ] * [ -1 0 1 ]  =  [ -1 ]   [  1  0 -1 ]  =  [  0  0  0 ]
02726   [  1 ]                  [  0 ]   [  0  0  0 ]     [ -1  0  1 ]
02727                           [  1 ]   [ -1  0  1 ]
02728 
02729 So be careful about what you really mean!
02730 
02731 Hint: throughout this module, whenever a vector is explicitly required
02732 for input, a B<COLUMN> vector is expected!
02733 
02734 =item *
02735 
02736 C<$matrix1-E<gt>add($matrix2,$matrix3);>
02737 
02738 Calculates the sum of matrix "C<$matrix2>" and matrix "C<$matrix3>"
02739 and stores the result in matrix "C<$matrix1>" (which must already exist
02740 and have the same size as matrix "C<$matrix2>" and matrix "C<$matrix3>"!).
02741 
02742 This operation can also be carried out "in-place", i.e., the output and
02743 one (or both) of the input matrices may be identical.
02744 
02745 =item *
02746 
02747 C<$matrix1-E<gt>subtract($matrix2,$matrix3);>
02748 
02749 Calculates the difference of matrix "C<$matrix2>" minus matrix "C<$matrix3>"
02750 and stores the result in matrix "C<$matrix1>" (which must already exist
02751 and have the same size as matrix "C<$matrix2>" and matrix "C<$matrix3>"!).
02752 
02753 This operation can also be carried out "in-place", i.e., the output and
02754 one (or both) of the input matrices may be identical.
02755 
02756 Note that this operation is the same as
02757 C<$matrix1-E<gt>add($matrix2,-$matrix3);>, although the latter is
02758 a little less efficient.
02759 
02760 =item *
02761 
02762 C<$matrix1-E<gt>multiply_scalar($matrix2,$scalar);>
02763 
02764 Calculates the product of matrix "C<$matrix2>" and the number "C<$scalar>"
02765 (i.e., multiplies each element of matrix "C<$matrix2>" with the factor
02766 "C<$scalar>") and stores the result in matrix "C<$matrix1>" (which must
02767 already exist and have the same size as matrix "C<$matrix2>"!).
02768 
02769 This operation can also be carried out "in-place", i.e., input and
02770 output matrix may be identical.
02771 
02772 =item *
02773 
02774 C<$product_matrix = $matrix1-E<gt>multiply($matrix2);>
02775 
02776 Calculates the product of matrix "C<$matrix1>" and matrix "C<$matrix2>"
02777 and returns an object reference to a new matrix "C<$product_matrix>" in
02778 which the result of this operation has been stored.
02779 
02780 Note that the dimensions of the two matrices "C<$matrix1>" and "C<$matrix2>"
02781 (i.e., their numbers of rows and columns) must harmonize in the following
02782 way (example):
02783 
02784                           [ 2 2 ]
02785                           [ 2 2 ]
02786                           [ 2 2 ]
02787 
02788               [ 1 1 1 ]   [ * * ]
02789               [ 1 1 1 ]   [ * * ]
02790               [ 1 1 1 ]   [ * * ]
02791               [ 1 1 1 ]   [ * * ]
02792 
02793 I.e., the number of columns of matrix "C<$matrix1>" has to be the same
02794 as the number of rows of matrix "C<$matrix2>".
02795 
02796 The number of rows and columns of the resulting matrix "C<$product_matrix>"
02797 is determined by the number of rows of matrix "C<$matrix1>" and the number
02798 of columns of matrix "C<$matrix2>", respectively.
02799 
02800 =item *
02801 
02802 C<$minimum = MatrixReal1::min($number1,$number2);>
02803 
02804 Returns the minimum of the two numbers "C<number1>" and "C<number2>".
02805 
02806 =item *
02807 
02808 C<$minimum = MatrixReal1::max($number1,$number2);>
02809 
02810 Returns the maximum of the two numbers "C<number1>" and "C<number2>".
02811 
02812 =item *
02813 
02814 C<$minimal_cost_matrix = $cost_matrix-E<gt>kleene();>
02815 
02816 Copies the matrix "C<$cost_matrix>" (which has to be quadratic!) to
02817 a new matrix of the same size (i.e., "clones" the input matrix) and
02818 applies Kleene's algorithm to it.
02819 
02820 See L<Math::Kleene(3)> for more details about this algorithm!
02821 
02822 The method returns an object reference to the new matrix.
02823 
02824 Matrix "C<$cost_matrix>" is not changed by this method in any way.
02825 
02826 =item *
02827 
02828 C<($norm_matrix,$norm_vector) = $matrix-E<gt>normalize($vector);>
02829 
02830 This method is used to improve the numerical stability when solving
02831 linear equation systems.
02832 
02833 Suppose you have a matrix "A" and a vector "b" and you want to find
02834 out a vector "x" so that C<A * x = b>, i.e., the vector "x" which
02835 solves the equation system represented by the matrix "A" and the
02836 vector "b".
02837 
02838 Applying this method to the pair (A,b) yields a pair (A',b') where
02839 each row has been divided by (the absolute value of) the greatest
02840 coefficient appearing in that row. So this coefficient becomes equal
02841 to "1" (or "-1") in the new pair (A',b') (all others become smaller
02842 than one and greater than minus one).
02843 
02844 Note that this operation does not change the equation system itself
02845 because the same division is carried out on either side of the equation
02846 sign!
02847 
02848 The method requires a quadratic (!) matrix "C<$matrix>" and a vector
02849 "C<$vector>" for input (the vector must be a column vector with the same
02850 number of rows as the input matrix) and returns a list of two items
02851 which are object references to a new matrix and a new vector, in this
02852 order.
02853 
02854 The output matrix and vector are clones of the input matrix and vector
02855 to which the operation explained above has been applied.
02856 
02857 The input matrix and vector are not changed by this in any way.
02858 
02859 Example of how this method can affect the result of the methods to solve
02860 equation systems (explained immediately below following this method):
02861 
02862 Consider the following little program:
02863 
02864   #!perl -w
02865 
02866   use MatrixReal1 qw(new_from_string);
02867 
02868   $A = MatrixReal1->new_from_string(<<"MATRIX");
02869   [  1   2   3  ]
02870   [  5   7  11  ]
02871   [ 23  19  13  ]
02872   MATRIX
02873 
02874   $b = MatrixReal1->new_from_string(<<"MATRIX");
02875   [   0   ]
02876   [   1   ]
02877   [  29   ]
02878   MATRIX
02879 
02880   $LR = $A->decompose_LR();
02881   if (($dim,$x,$B) = $LR->solve_LR($b))
02882   {
02883       $test = $A * $x;
02884       print "x = \n$x";
02885       print "A * x = \n$test";
02886   }
02887 
02888   ($A_,$b_) = $A->normalize($b);
02889 
02890   $LR = $A_->decompose_LR();
02891   if (($dim,$x,$B) = $LR->solve_LR($b_))
02892   {
02893       $test = $A * $x;
02894       print "x = \n$x";
02895       print "A * x = \n$test";
02896   }
02897 
02898 This will print:
02899 
02900   x =
02901   [  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02902   [  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02903   [ -1.000000000000E+00 ]
02904   A * x =
02905   [  4.440892098501E-16 ]
02906   [  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02907   [  2.900000000000E+01 ]
02908   x =
02909   [  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02910   [  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02911   [ -1.000000000000E+00 ]
02912   A * x =
02913   [  0.000000000000E+00 ]
02914   [  1.000000000000E+00 ]
02915   [  2.900000000000E+01 ]
02916 
02917 You can see that in the second example (where "normalize()" has been used),
02918 the result is "better", i.e., more accurate!
02919 
02920 =item *
02921 
02922 C<$LR_matrix = $matrix-E<gt>decompose_LR();>
02923 
02924 This method is needed to solve linear equation systems.
02925 
02926 Suppose you have a matrix "A" and a vector "b" and you want to find
02927 out a vector "x" so that C<A * x = b>, i.e., the vector "x" which
02928 solves the equation system represented by the matrix "A" and the
02929 vector "b".
02930 
02931 You might also have a matrix "A" and a whole bunch of different
02932 vectors "b1".."bk" for which you need to find vectors "x1".."xk"
02933 so that C<A * xi = bi>, for C<i=1..k>.
02934 
02935 Using Gaussian transformations (multiplying a row or column with
02936 a factor, swapping two rows or two columns and adding a multiple
02937 of one row or column to another), it is possible to decompose any
02938 matrix "A" into two triangular matrices, called "L" and "R" (for
02939 "Left" and "Right").
02940 
02941 "L" has one's on the main diagonal (the elements (1,1), (2,2), (3,3)
02942 and so so), non-zero values to the left and below of the main diagonal
02943 and all zero's in the upper right half of the matrix.
02944 
02945 "R" has non-zero values on the main diagonal as well as to the right
02946 and above of the main diagonal and all zero's in the lower left half
02947 of the matrix, as follows:
02948 
02949           [ 1 0 0 0 0 ]      [ x x x x x ]
02950           [ x 1 0 0 0 ]      [ 0 x x x x ]
02951       L = [ x x 1 0 0 ]  R = [ 0 0 x x x ]
02952           [ x x x 1 0 ]      [ 0 0 0 x x ]
02953           [ x x x x 1 ]      [ 0 0 0 0 x ]
02954 
02955 Note that "C<L * R>" is equivalent to matrix "A" in the sense that
02956 C<L * R * x = b  E<lt>==E<gt>  A * x = b> for all vectors "x", leaving
02957 out of account permutations of the rows and columns (these are taken
02958 care of "magically" by this module!) and numerical errors.
02959 
02960 Trick:
02961 
02962 Because we know that "L" has one's on its main diagonal, we can
02963 store both matrices together in the same array without information
02964 loss! I.e.,
02965 
02966                  [ R R R R R ]
02967                  [ L R R R R ]
02968             LR = [ L L R R R ]
02969                  [ L L L R R ]
02970                  [ L L L L R ]
02971 
02972 Beware, though, that "LR" and "C<L * R>" are not the same!!!
02973 
02974 Note also that for the same reason, you cannot apply the method "normalize()"
02975 to an "LR" decomposition matrix. Trying to do so will yield meaningless
02976 rubbish!
02977 
02978 (You need to apply "normalize()" to each pair (Ai,bi) B<BEFORE> decomposing
02979 the matrix "Ai'"!)
02980 
02981 Now what does all this help us in solving linear equation systems?
02982 
02983 It helps us because a triangular matrix is the next best thing
02984 that can happen to us besides a diagonal matrix (a matrix that
02985 has non-zero values only on its main diagonal - in which case
02986 the solution is trivial, simply divide "C<b[i]>" by "C<A[i,i]>"
02987 to get "C<x[i]>"!).
02988 
02989 To find the solution to our problem "C<A * x = b>", we divide this
02990 problem in parts: instead of solving C<A * x = b> directly, we first
02991 decompose "A" into "L" and "R" and then solve "C<L * y = b>" and
02992 finally "C<R * x = y>" (motto: divide and rule!).
02993 
02994 From the illustration above it is clear that solving "C<L * y = b>"
02995 and "C<R * x = y>" is straightforward: we immediately know that
02996 C<y[1] = b[1]>. We then deduce swiftly that
02997 
02998   y[2] = b[2] - L[2,1] * y[1]
02999 
03000 (and we know "C<y[1]>" by now!), that
03001 
03002   y[3] = b[3] - L[3,1] * y[1] - L[3,2] * y[2]
03003 
03004 and so on.
03005 
03006 Having effortlessly calculated the vector "y", we now proceed to
03007 calculate the vector "x" in a similar fashion: we see immediately
03008 that C<x[n] = y[n] / R[n,n]>. It follows that
03009 
03010   x[n-1] = ( y[n-1] - R[n-1,n] * x[n] ) / R[n-1,n-1]
03011 
03012 and
03013 
03014   x[n-2] = ( y[n-2] - R[n-2,n-1] * x[n-1] - R[n-2,n] * x[n] )
03015            / R[n-2,n-2]
03016 
03017 and so on.
03018 
03019 You can see that - especially when you have many vectors "b1".."bk"
03020 for which you are searching solutions to C<A * xi = bi> - this scheme
03021 is much more efficient than a straightforward, "brute force" approach.
03022 
03023 This method requires a quadratic matrix as its input matrix.
03024 
03025 If you don't have that many equations, fill up with zero's (i.e., do
03026 nothing to fill the superfluous rows if it's a "fresh" matrix, i.e.,
03027 a matrix that has been created with "new()" or "shadow()").
03028 
03029 The method returns an object reference to a new matrix containing the
03030 matrices "L" and "R".
03031 
03032 The input matrix is not changed by this method in any way.
03033 
03034 Note that you can "copy()" or "clone()" the result of this method without
03035 losing its "magical" properties (for instance concerning the hidden
03036 permutations of its rows and columns).
03037 
03038 However, as soon as you are applying any method that alters the contents
03039 of the matrix, its "magical" properties are stripped off, and the matrix
03040 immediately reverts to an "ordinary" matrix (with the values it just happens
03041 to contain at that moment, be they meaningful as an ordinary matrix or not!).
03042 
03043 =item *
03044 
03045 C<($dimension,$x_vector,$base_matrix) = $LR_matrix>C<-E<gt>>C<solve_LR($b_vector);>
03046 
03047 Use this method to actually solve an equation system.
03048 
03049 Matrix "C<$LR_matrix>" must be a (quadratic) matrix returned by the
03050 method "decompose_LR()", the LR decomposition matrix of the matrix
03051 "A" of your equation system C<A * x = b>.
03052 
03053 The input vector "C<$b_vector>" is the vector "b" in your equation system
03054 C<A * x = b>, which must be a column vector and have the same number of
03055 rows as the input matrix "C<$LR_matrix>".
03056 
03057 The method returns a list of three items if a solution exists or an
03058 empty list otherwise (!).
03059 
03060 Therefore, you should always use this method like this:
03061 
03062   if ( ($dim,$x_vec,$base) = $LR->solve_LR($b_vec) )
03063   {
03064       # do something with the solution...
03065   }
03066   else
03067   {
03068       # do something with the fact that there is no solution...
03069   }
03070 
03071 The three items returned are: the dimension "C<$dimension>" of the solution
03072 space (which is zero if only one solution exists, one if the solution is
03073 a straight line, two if the solution is a plane, and so on), the solution
03074 vector "C<$x_vector>" (which is the vector "x" of your equation system
03075 C<A * x = b>) and a matrix "C<$base_matrix>" representing a base of the
03076 solution space (a set of vectors which put up the solution space like
03077 the spokes of an umbrella).
03078 
03079 Only the first "C<$dimension>" columns of this base matrix actually
03080 contain entries, the remaining columns are all zero.
03081 
03082 Now what is all this stuff with that "base" good for?
03083 
03084 The output vector "x" is B<ALWAYS> a solution of your equation system
03085 C<A * x = b>.
03086 
03087 But also any vector "C<$vector>"
03088 
03089   $vector = $x_vector->clone();
03090 
03091   $machine_infinity = 1E+99; # or something like that
03092 
03093   for ( $i = 1; $i <= $dimension; $i++ )
03094   {
03095       $vector += rand($machine_infinity) * $base_matrix->column($i);
03096   }
03097 
03098 is a solution to your problem C<A * x = b>, i.e., if "C<$A_matrix>" contains
03099 your matrix "A", then
03100 
03101   print abs( $A_matrix * $vector - $b_vector ), "\n";
03102 
03103 should print a number around 1E-16 or so!
03104 
03105 By the way, note that you can actually calculate those vectors "C<$vector>"
03106 a little more efficient as follows:
03107 
03108   $rand_vector = $x_vector->shadow();
03109 
03110   $machine_infinity = 1E+99; # or something like that
03111 
03112   for ( $i = 1; $i <= $dimension; $i++ )
03113   {
03114       $rand_vector->assign($i,1, rand($machine_infinity) );
03115   }
03116 
03117   $vector = $x_vector + ( $base_matrix * $rand_vector );
03118 
03119 Note that the input matrix and vector are not changed by this method
03120 in any way.
03121 
03122 =item *
03123 
03124 C<$inverse_matrix = $LR_matrix-E<gt>invert_LR();>
03125 
03126 Use this method to calculate the inverse of a given matrix "C<$LR_matrix>",
03127 which must be a (quadratic) matrix returned by the method "decompose_LR()".
03128 
03129 The method returns an object reference to a new matrix of the same size as
03130 the input matrix containing the inverse of the matrix that you initially
03131 fed into "decompose_LR()" B<IF THE INVERSE EXISTS>, or an empty list
03132 otherwise.
03133 
03134 Therefore, you should always use this method in the following way:
03135 
03136   if ( $inverse_matrix = $LR->invert_LR() )
03137   {
03138       # do something with the inverse matrix...
03139   }
03140   else
03141   {
03142       # do something with the fact that there is no inverse matrix...
03143   }
03144 
03145 Note that by definition (disregarding numerical errors), the product
03146 of the initial matrix and its inverse (or vice-versa) is always a matrix
03147 containing one's on the main diagonal (elements (1,1), (2,2), (3,3) and
03148 so on) and zero's elsewhere.
03149 
03150 The input matrix is not changed by this method in any way.
03151 
03152 =item *
03153 
03154 C<$condition = $matrix-E<gt>condition($inverse_matrix);>
03155 
03156 In fact this method is just a shortcut for
03157 
03158   abs($matrix) * abs($inverse_matrix)
03159 
03160 Both input matrices must be quadratic and have the same size, and the result
03161 is meaningful only if one of them is the inverse of the other (for instance,
03162 as returned by the method "invert_LR()").
03163 
03164 The number returned is a measure of the "condition" of the given matrix
03165 "C<$matrix>", i.e., a measure of the numerical stability of the matrix.
03166 
03167 This number is always positive, and the smaller its value, the better the
03168 condition of the matrix (the better the stability of all subsequent
03169 computations carried out using this matrix).
03170 
03171 Numerical stability means for example that if
03172 
03173   abs( $vec_correct - $vec_with_error ) < $epsilon
03174 
03175 holds, there must be a "C<$delta>" which doesn't depend on the vector
03176 "C<$vec_correct>" (nor "C<$vec_with_error>", by the way) so that
03177 
03178   abs( $matrix * $vec_correct - $matrix * $vec_with_error ) < $delta
03179 
03180 also holds.
03181 
03182 =item *
03183 
03184 C<$determinant = $LR_matrix-E<gt>det_LR();>
03185 
03186 Calculates the determinant of a matrix, whose LR decomposition matrix
03187 "C<$LR_matrix>" must be given (which must be a (quadratic) matrix
03188 returned by the method "decompose_LR()").
03189 
03190 In fact the determinant is a by-product of the LR decomposition: It is
03191 (in principle, that is, except for the sign) simply the product of the
03192 elements on the main diagonal (elements (1,1), (2,2), (3,3) and so on)
03193 of the LR decomposition matrix.
03194 
03195 (The sign is taken care of "magically" by this module)
03196 
03197 =item *
03198 
03199 C<$order = $LR_matrix-E<gt>order_LR();>
03200 
03201 Calculates the order (called "Rang" in German) of a matrix, whose
03202 LR decomposition matrix "C<$LR_matrix>" must be given (which must
03203 be a (quadratic) matrix returned by the method "decompose_LR()").
03204 
03205 This number is a measure of the number of linear independent row
03206 and column vectors (= number of linear independent equations in
03207 the case of a matrix representing an equation system) of the
03208 matrix that was initially fed into "decompose_LR()".
03209 
03210 If "n" is the number of rows and columns of the (quadratic!) matrix,
03211 then "n - order" is the dimension of the solution space of the
03212 associated equation system.
03213 
03214 =item *
03215 
03216 C<$scalar_product = $vector1-E<gt>scalar_product($vector2);>
03217 
03218 Returns the scalar product of vector "C<$vector1>" and vector "C<$vector2>".
03219 
03220 Both vectors must be column vectors (i.e., a matrix having
03221 several rows but only one column).
03222 
03223 This is a (more efficient!) shortcut for
03224 
03225   $temp           = ~$vector1 * $vector2;
03226   $scalar_product =  $temp->element(1,1);
03227 
03228 or the sum C<i=1..n> of the products C<vector1[i] * vector2[i]>.
03229 
03230 Provided none of the two input vectors is the null vector, then
03231 the two vectors are orthogonal, i.e., have an angle of 90 degrees
03232 between them, exactly when their scalar product is zero, and
03233 vice-versa.
03234 
03235 =item *
03236 
03237 C<$vector_product = $vector1-E<gt>vector_product($vector2);>
03238 
03239 Returns the vector product of vector "C<$vector1>" and vector "C<$vector2>".
03240 
03241 Both vectors must be column vectors (i.e., a matrix having several rows
03242 but only one column).
03243 
03244 Currently, the vector product is only defined for 3 dimensions (i.e.,
03245 vectors with 3 rows); all other vectors trigger an error message.
03246 
03247 In 3 dimensions, the vector product of two vectors "x" and "y"
03248 is defined as
03249 
03250               |  x[1]  y[1]  e[1]  |
03251   determinant |  x[2]  y[2]  e[2]  |
03252               |  x[3]  y[3]  e[3]  |
03253 
03254 where the "C<x[i]>" and "C<y[i]>" are the components of the two vectors
03255 "x" and "y", respectively, and the "C<e[i]>" are unity vectors (i.e.,
03256 vectors with a length equal to one) with a one in row "i" and zero's
03257 elsewhere (this means that you have numbers and vectors as elements
03258 in this matrix!).
03259 
03260 This determinant evaluates to the rather simple formula
03261 
03262   z[1] = x[2] * y[3] - x[3] * y[2]
03263   z[2] = x[3] * y[1] - x[1] * y[3]
03264   z[3] = x[1] * y[2] - x[2] * y[1]
03265 
03266 A characteristic property of the vector product is that the resulting
03267 vector is orthogonal to both of the input vectors (if neither of both
03268 is the null vector, otherwise this is trivial), i.e., the scalar product
03269 of each of the input vectors with the resulting vector is always zero.
03270 
03271 =item *
03272 
03273 C<$length = $vector-E<gt>length();>
03274 
03275 This is actually a shortcut for
03276 
03277   $length = sqrt( $vector->scalar_product($vector) );
03278 
03279 and returns the length of a given (column!) vector "C<$vector>".
03280 
03281 Note that the "length" calculated by this method is in fact the
03282 "two"-norm of a vector "C<$vector>"!
03283 
03284 The general definition for norms of vectors is the following:
03285 
03286   sub vector_norm
03287   {
03288       croak "Usage: \$norm = \$vector->vector_norm(\$n);"
03289         if (@_ != 2);
03290 
03291       my($vector,$n) = @_;
03292       my($rows,$cols) = ($vector->[1],$vector->[2]);
03293       my($k,$comp,$sum);
03294 
03295       croak "MatrixReal1::vector_norm(): vector is not a column vector"
03296         unless ($cols == 1);
03297 
03298       croak "MatrixReal1::vector_norm(): norm index must be > 0"
03299         unless ($n > 0);
03300 
03301       croak "MatrixReal1::vector_norm(): norm index must be integer"
03302         unless ($n == int($n));
03303 
03304       $sum = 0;
03305       for ( $k = 0; $k < $rows; $k++ )
03306       {
03307           $comp = abs( $vector->[0][$k][0] );
03308           $sum += $comp ** $n;
03309       }
03310       return( $sum ** (1 / $n) );
03311   }
03312 
03313 Note that the case "n = 1" is the "one"-norm for matrices applied to a
03314 vector, the case "n = 2" is the euclidian norm or length of a vector,
03315 and if "n" goes to infinity, you have the "infinity"- or "maximum"-norm
03316 for matrices applied to a vector!
03317 
03318 =item *
03319 
03320 C<$xn_vector = $matrix-E<gt>>C<solve_GSM($x0_vector,$b_vector,$epsilon);>
03321 
03322 =item *
03323 
03324 C<$xn_vector = $matrix-E<gt>>C<solve_SSM($x0_vector,$b_vector,$epsilon);>
03325 
03326 =item *
03327 
03328 C<$xn_vector = $matrix-E<gt>>C<solve_RM($x0_vector,$b_vector,$weight,$epsilon);>
03329 
03330 In some cases it might not be practical or desirable to solve an
03331 equation system "C<A * x = b>" using an analytical algorithm like
03332 the "decompose_LR()" and "solve_LR()" method pair.
03333 
03334 In fact in some cases, due to the numerical properties (the "condition")
03335 of the matrix "A", the numerical error of the obtained result can be
03336 greater than by using an approximative (iterative) algorithm like one
03337 of the three implemented here.
03338 
03339 All three methods, GSM ("Global Step Method" or "Gesamtschrittverfahren"),
03340 SSM ("Single Step Method" or "Einzelschrittverfahren") and RM ("Relaxation
03341 Method" or "Relaxationsverfahren"), are fix-point iterations, that is, can
03342 be described by an iteration function "C<x(t+1) = Phi( x(t) )>" which has
03343 the property:
03344 
03345   Phi(x)  =  x    <==>    A * x  =  b
03346 
03347 We can define "C<Phi(x)>" as follows:
03348 
03349   Phi(x)  :=  ( En - A ) * x  +  b
03350 
03351 where "En" is a matrix of the same size as "A" ("n" rows and columns)
03352 with one's on its main diagonal and zero's elsewhere.
03353 
03354 This function has the required property.
03355 
03356 Proof:
03357 
03358            A * x        =   b
03359 
03360   <==>  -( A * x )      =  -b
03361 
03362   <==>  -( A * x ) + x  =  -b + x
03363 
03364   <==>  -( A * x ) + x + b  =  x
03365 
03366   <==>  x - ( A * x ) + b  =  x
03367 
03368   <==>  ( En - A ) * x + b  =  x
03369 
03370 This last step is true because
03371 
03372   x[i] - ( a[i,1] x[1] + ... + a[i,i] x[i] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] ) + b[i]
03373 
03374 is the same as
03375 
03376   ( -a[i,1] x[1] + ... + (1 - a[i,i]) x[i] + ... + -a[i,n] x[n] ) + b[i]
03377 
03378 qed
03379 
03380 Note that actually solving the equation system "C<A * x = b>" means
03381 to calculate
03382 
03383         a[i,1] x[1] + ... + a[i,i] x[i] + ... + a[i,n] x[n]  =  b[i]
03384 
03385   <==>  a[i,i] x[i]  =
03386         b[i]
03387         - ( a[i,1] x[1] + ... + a[i,i] x[i] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] )
03388         + a[i,i] x[i]
03389 
03390   <==>  x[i]  =
03391         ( b[i]
03392             - ( a[i,1] x[1] + ... + a[i,i] x[i] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] )
03393             + a[i,i] x[i]
03394         ) / a[i,i]
03395 
03396   <==>  x[i]  =
03397         ( b[i] -
03398             ( a[i,1] x[1] + ... + a[i,i-1] x[i-1] +
03399               a[i,i+1] x[i+1] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] )
03400         ) / a[i,i]
03401 
03402 There is one major restriction, though: a fix-point iteration is
03403 guaranteed to converge only if the first derivative of the iteration
03404 function has an absolute value less than one in an area around the
03405 point "C<x(*)>" for which "C<Phi( x(*) ) = x(*)>" is to be true, and
03406 if the start vector "C<x(0)>" lies within that area!
03407 
03408 This is best verified grafically, which unfortunately is impossible
03409 to do in this textual documentation!
03410 
03411 See literature on Numerical Analysis for details!
03412 
03413 In our case, this restriction translates to the following three conditions:
03414 
03415 There must exist a norm so that the norm of the matrix of the iteration
03416 function, C<( En - A )>, has a value less than one, the matrix "A" may
03417 not have any zero value on its main diagonal and the initial vector
03418 "C<x(0)>" must be "good enough", i.e., "close enough" to the solution
03419 "C<x(*)>".
03420 
03421 (Remember school math: the first derivative of a straight line given by
03422 "C<y = a * x + b>" is "a"!)
03423 
03424 The three methods expect a (quadratic!) matrix "C<$matrix>" as their
03425 first argument, a start vector "C<$x0_vector>", a vector "C<$b_vector>"
03426 (which is the vector "b" in your equation system "C<A * x = b>"), in the
03427 case of the "Relaxation Method" ("RM"), a real number "C<$weight>" best
03428 between zero and two, and finally an error limit (real number) "C<$epsilon>".
03429 
03430 (Note that the weight "C<$weight>" used by the "Relaxation Method" ("RM")
03431 is B<NOT> checked to lie within any reasonable range!)
03432 
03433 The three methods first test the first two conditions of the three
03434 conditions listed above and return an empty list if these conditions
03435 are not fulfilled.
03436 
03437 Therefore, you should always test their return value using some
03438 code like:
03439 
03440   if ( $xn_vector = $A_matrix->solve_GSM($x0_vector,$b_vector,1E-12) )
03441   {
03442       # do something with the solution...
03443   }
03444   else
03445   {
03446       # do something with the fact that there is no solution...
03447   }
03448 
03449 Otherwise, they iterate until C<abs( Phi(x) - x ) E<lt> epsilon>.
03450 
03451 (Beware that theoretically, infinite loops might result if the starting
03452 vector is too far "off" the solution! In practice, this shouldn't be
03453 a problem. Anyway, you can always press <ctrl-C> if you think that the
03454 iteration takes too long!)
03455 
03456 The difference between the three methods is the following:
03457 
03458 In the "Global Step Method" ("GSM"), the new vector "C<x(t+1)>"
03459 (called "y" here) is calculated from the vector "C<x(t)>"
03460 (called "x" here) according to the formula:
03461 
03462   y[i] =
03463   ( b[i]
03464       - ( a[i,1] x[1] + ... + a[i,i-1] x[i-1] +
03465           a[i,i+1] x[i+1] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] )
03466   ) / a[i,i]
03467 
03468 In the "Single Step Method" ("SSM"), the components of the vector
03469 "C<x(t+1)>" which have already been calculated are used to calculate
03470 the remaining components, i.e.
03471 
03472   y[i] =
03473   ( b[i]
03474       - ( a[i,1] y[1] + ... + a[i,i-1] y[i-1] +  # note the "y[]"!
03475           a[i,i+1] x[i+1] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] )  # note the "x[]"!
03476   ) / a[i,i]
03477 
03478 In the "Relaxation method" ("RM"), the components of the vector
03479 "C<x(t+1)>" are calculated by "mixing" old and new value (like
03480 cold and hot water), and the weight "C<$weight>" determines the
03481 "aperture" of both the "hot water tap" as well as of the "cold
03482 water tap", according to the formula:
03483 
03484   y[i] =
03485   ( b[i]
03486       - ( a[i,1] y[1] + ... + a[i,i-1] y[i-1] +  # note the "y[]"!
03487           a[i,i+1] x[i+1] + ... + a[i,n] x[n] )  # note the "x[]"!
03488   ) / a[i,i]
03489   y[i] = weight * y[i] + (1 - weight) * x[i]
03490 
03491 Note that the weight "C<$weight>" should be greater than zero and
03492 less than two (!).
03493 
03494 The three methods are supposed to be of different efficiency.
03495 Experiment!
03496 
03497 Remember that in most cases, it is probably advantageous to first
03498 "normalize()" your equation system prior to solving it!
03499 
03500 =back
03501 
03502 =head2 Eigensystems
03503 
03504 =over 2
03505 
03506 =item *
03507 
03508 C<$matrix-E<gt>is_symmetric();>
03509 
03510 Returns a boolean value indicating if the given matrix is
03511 symmetric (B<M>[I<i>,I<j>]=B<M>[I<j>,I<i>]). This is equivalent to 
03512 C<($matrix == ~$matrix)> but without memory allocation.
03513 
03514 =item *
03515 
03516 C<($l, $V) = $matrix-E<gt>sym_diagonalize();>
03517 
03518 This method performs the diagonalization of the quadratic
03519 I<symmetric> matrix B<M> stored in $matrix.
03520 On output, B<l> is a column vector containing all the eigenvalues
03521 of B<M> and B<V> is an orthogonal matrix which columns are the
03522 corresponding normalized eigenvectors.
03523 The primary property of an eigenvalue I<l> and an eigenvector
03524 B<x> is of course that: B<M> * B<x> = I<l> * B<x>.
03525 
03526 The method uses a Householder reduction to tridiagonal form
03527 followed by a QL algoritm with implicit shifts on this
03528 tridiagonal. (The tridiagonal matrix is kept internally
03529 in a compact form in this routine to save memory.)
03530 In fact, this routine wraps the householder() and
03531 tri_diagonalize() methods described below when their
03532 intermediate results are not desired.
03533 The overall algorithmic complexity of this technique
03534 is O(N^3). According to several books, the coefficient
03535 hidden by the 'O' is one of the best possible for general
03536 (symmetric) matrixes.
03537 
03538 =item *
03539 
03540 C<($T, $Q) = $matrix-E<gt>householder();>
03541 
03542 This method performs the Householder algorithm which reduces
03543 the I<n> by I<n> real I<symmetric> matrix B<M> contained
03544 in $matrix to tridiagonal form.
03545 On output, B<T> is a symmetric tridiagonal matrix (only
03546 diagonal and off-diagonal elements are non-zero) and B<Q>
03547 is an I<orthogonal> matrix performing the tranformation
03548 between B<M> and B<T> (C<$M == $Q * $T * ~$Q>).
03549 
03550 =item *
03551 
03552 C<($l, $V) = $T-E<gt>tri_diagonalize([$Q]);>
03553 
03554 This method diagonalizes the symmetric tridiagonal
03555 matrix B<T>. On output, $l and $V are similar to the
03556 output values described for sym_diagonalize().
03557 
03558 The optional argument $Q corresponds to an orthogonal
03559 transformation matrix B<Q> that should be used additionally
03560 during B<V> (eigenvectors) computation. It should be supplied
03561 if the desired eigenvectors correspond to a more general
03562 symmetric matrix B<M> previously reduced by the
03563 householder() method, not a mere tridiagonal. If B<T> is
03564 really a tridiagonal matrix, B<Q> can be omitted (it
03565 will be internally created in fact as an identity matrix).
03566 The method uses a QL algorithm (with implicit shifts).
03567 
03568 =item *
03569 
03570 C<$l = $matrix-E<gt>sym_eigenvalues();>
03571 
03572 This method computes the eigenvalues of the quadratic
03573 I<symmetric> matrix B<M> stored in $matrix.
03574 On output, B<l> is a column vector containing all the eigenvalues
03575 of B<M>. Eigenvectors are not computed (on the contrary of
03576 C<sym_diagonalize()>) and this method is more efficient
03577 (even though it uses a similar algorithm with two phases).
03578 However, understand that the algorithmic complexity of this
03579 technique is still also O(N^3). But the coefficient hidden
03580 by the 'O' is better by a factor of..., well, see your
03581 benchmark, it's wiser.
03582 
03583 This routine wraps the householder_tridiagonal() and
03584 tri_eigenvalues() methods described below when the
03585 intermediate tridiagonal matrix is not needed.
03586 
03587 =item *
03588 
03589 C<$T = $matrix-E<gt>householder_tridiagonal();>
03590 
03591 This method performs the Householder algorithm which reduces
03592 the I<n> by I<n> real I<symmetric> matrix B<M> contained
03593 in $matrix to tridiagonal form.
03594 On output, B<T> is the obtained symmetric tridiagonal matrix
03595 (only diagonal and off-diagonal elements are non-zero). The
03596 operation is similar to the householder() method, but potentially
03597 a little more efficient as the transformation matrix is not
03598 computed.
03599 
03600 =item *
03601 
03602 C<$l = $T-E<gt>tri_eigenvalues();>
03603 
03604 This method compute the eigenvalues of the symmetric
03605 tridiagonal matrix B<T>. On output, $l is a vector
03606 containing the eigenvalues (similar to C<sym_eigenvalues()>).
03607 This method is much more efficient than tri_diagonalize()
03608 when eigenvectors are not needed.
03609 
03610 =back
03611 
03612 =head1 OVERLOADED OPERATORS
03613 
03614 =head2 SYNOPSIS
03615 
03616 =over 2
03617 
03618 =item *
03619 
03620 Unary operators:
03621 
03622 "C<->", "C<~>", "C<abs>", C<test>, "C<!>", 'C<"">'
03623 
03624 =item *
03625 
03626 Binary (arithmetic) operators:
03627 
03628 "C<+>", "C<->", "C<*>"
03629 
03630 =item *
03631 
03632 Binary (relational) operators:
03633 
03634 "C<==>", "C<!=>", "C<E<lt>>", "C<E<lt>=>", "C<E<gt>>", "C<E<gt>=>"
03635 
03636 "C<eq>", "C<ne>", "C<lt>", "C<le>", "C<gt>", "C<ge>"
03637 
03638 Note that the latter ("C<eq>", "C<ne>", ... ) are just synonyms
03639 of the former ("C<==>", "C<!=>", ... ), defined for convenience
03640 only.
03641 
03642 =back
03643 
03644 =head2 DESCRIPTION
03645 
03646 =over 5
03647 
03648 =item '-'
03649 
03650 Unary minus
03651 
03652 Returns the negative of the given matrix, i.e., the matrix with
03653 all elements multiplied with the factor "-1".
03654 
03655 Example:
03656 
03657     $matrix = -$matrix;
03658 
03659 =item '~'
03660 
03661 Transposition
03662 
03663 Returns the transposed of the given matrix.
03664 
03665 Examples:
03666 
03667     $temp = ~$vector * $vector;
03668     $length = sqrt( $temp->element(1,1) );
03669 
03670     if (~$matrix == $matrix) { # matrix is symmetric ... }
03671 
03672 =item abs
03673 
03674 Norm
03675 
03676 Returns the "one"-Norm of the given matrix.
03677 
03678 Example:
03679 
03680     $error = abs( $A * $x - $b );
03681 
03682 =item test
03683 
03684 Boolean test
03685 
03686 Tests wether there is at least one non-zero element in the matrix.
03687 
03688 Example:
03689 
03690     if ($xn_vector) { # result of iteration is not zero ... }
03691 
03692 =item '!'
03693 
03694 Negated boolean test
03695 
03696 Tests wether the matrix contains only zero's.
03697 
03698 Examples:
03699 
03700     if (! $b_vector) { # heterogenous equation system ... }
03701     else             { # homogenous equation system ... }
03702 
03703     unless ($x_vector) { # not the null-vector! }
03704 
03705 =item '""""'
03706 
03707 "Stringify" operator
03708 
03709 Converts the given matrix into a string.
03710 
03711 Uses scientific representation to keep precision loss to a minimum in case
03712 you want to read this string back in again later with "new_from_string()".
03713 
03714 Uses a 13-digit mantissa and a 20-character field for each element so that
03715 lines will wrap nicely on an 80-column screen.
03716 
03717 Examples:
03718 
03719     $matrix = MatrixReal1->new_from_string(<<"MATRIX");
03720     [ 1  0 ]
03721     [ 0 -1 ]
03722     MATRIX
03723     print "$matrix";
03724 
03725     [  1.000000000000E+00  0.000000000000E+00 ]
03726     [  0.000000000000E+00 -1.000000000000E+00 ]
03727 
03728     $string = "$matrix";
03729     $test = MatrixReal1->new_from_string($string);
03730     if ($test == $matrix) { print ":-)\n"; } else { print ":-(\n"; }
03731 
03732 =item '+'
03733 
03734 Addition
03735 
03736 Returns the sum of the two given matrices.
03737 
03738 Examples:
03739 
03740     $matrix_S = $matrix_A + $matrix_B;
03741 
03742     $matrix_A += $matrix_B;
03743 
03744 =item '-'
03745 
03746 Subtraction
03747 
03748 Returns the difference of the two given matrices.
03749 
03750 Examples:
03751 
03752     $matrix_D = $matrix_A - $matrix_B;
03753 
03754     $matrix_A -= $matrix_B;
03755 
03756 Note that this is the same as:
03757 
03758     $matrix_S = $matrix_A + -$matrix_B;
03759 
03760     $matrix_A += -$matrix_B;
03761 
03762 (The latter are less efficient, though)
03763 
03764 =item '*'
03765 
03766 Multiplication
03767 
03768 Returns the matrix product of the two given matrices or
03769 the product of the given matrix and scalar factor.
03770 
03771 Examples:
03772 
03773     $matrix_P = $matrix_A * $matrix_B;
03774 
03775     $matrix_A *= $matrix_B;
03776 
03777     $vector_b = $matrix_A * $vector_x;
03778 
03779     $matrix_B = -1 * $matrix_A;
03780 
03781     $matrix_B = $matrix_A * -1;
03782 
03783     $matrix_A *= -1;
03784 
03785 =item '=='
03786 
03787 Equality
03788 
03789 Tests two matrices for equality.
03790 
03791 Example:
03792 
03793     if ( $A * $x == $b ) { print "EUREKA!\n"; }
03794 
03795 Note that in most cases, due to numerical errors (due to the finite
03796 precision of computer arithmetics), it is a bad idea to compare two
03797 matrices or vectors this way.
03798 
03799 Better use the norm of the difference of the two matrices you want
03800 to compare and compare that norm with a small number, like this:
03801 
03802     if ( abs( $A * $x - $b ) < 1E-12 ) { print "BINGO!\n"; }
03803 
03804 =item '!='
03805 
03806 Inequality
03807 
03808 Tests two matrices for inequality.
03809 
03810 Example:
03811 
03812     while ($x0_vector != $xn_vector) { # proceed with iteration ... }
03813 
03814 (Stops when the iteration becomes stationary)
03815 
03816 Note that (just like with the '==' operator), it is usually a bad idea
03817 to compare matrices or vectors this way. Compare the norm of the difference
03818 of the two matrices with a small number instead.
03819 
03820 =item 'E<lt>'
03821 
03822 Less than
03823 
03824 Examples:
03825 
03826     if ( $matrix1 < $matrix2 ) { # ... }
03827 
03828     if ( $vector < $epsilon ) { # ... }
03829 
03830     if ( 1E-12 < $vector ) { # ... }
03831 
03832     if ( $A * $x - $b < 1E-12 ) { # ... }
03833 
03834 These are just shortcuts for saying:
03835 
03836     if ( abs($matrix1) < abs($matrix2) ) { # ... }
03837 
03838     if ( abs($vector) < abs($epsilon) ) { # ... }
03839 
03840     if ( abs(1E-12) < abs($vector) ) { # ... }
03841 
03842     if ( abs( $A * $x - $b ) < abs(1E-12) ) { # ... }
03843 
03844 Uses the "one"-norm for matrices and Perl's built-in "abs()" for scalars.
03845 
03846 =item 'E<lt>='
03847 
03848 Less than or equal
03849 
03850 As with the '<' operator, this is just a shortcut for the same expression
03851 with "abs()" around all arguments.
03852 
03853 Example:
03854 
03855     if ( $A * $x - $b <= 1E-12 ) { # ... }
03856 
03857 which in fact is the same as:
03858 
03859     if ( abs( $A * $x - $b ) <= abs(1E-12) ) { # ... }
03860 
03861 Uses the "one"-norm for matrices and Perl's built-in "abs()" for scalars.
03862 
03863 =item 'E<gt>'
03864 
03865 Greater than
03866 
03867 As with the '<' and '<=' operator, this
03868 
03869     if ( $xn - $x0 > 1E-12 ) { # ... }
03870 
03871 is just a shortcut for:
03872 
03873     if ( abs( $xn - $x0 ) > abs(1E-12) ) { # ... }
03874 
03875 Uses the "one"-norm for matrices and Perl's built-in "abs()" for scalars.
03876 
03877 =item 'E<gt>='
03878 
03879 Greater than or equal
03880 
03881 As with the '<', '<=' and '>' operator, the following
03882 
03883     if ( $LR >= $A ) { # ... }
03884 
03885 is simply a shortcut for:
03886 
03887     if ( abs($LR) >= abs($A) ) { # ... }
03888 
03889 Uses the "one"-norm for matrices and Perl's built-in "abs()" for scalars.
03890 
03891 =back
03892

03894

03896 Set::IntegerRange(3), Set::IntegerFast(3).
